As discussed at a Georgia school system meeting; H1b teachers spend the first year finding the way to work (acclimating), the second year learning the communication skills and can finally perform the job the third year, after which their visa expires.  As a tax payer and a parent I am furious. As the parent of a child with learning disabilities I don't understand why an extra hurdle to learning is given to my child.  I see this in my workplace also. My experience has been that H1b visa holders are rarely appropriately placed in any position.

EN, you writie:

"Our real skill gap is our lack of STEMS degree holders who actually learned how to be scientists and engineers".

Considering the fact that 16% of all PhD chemists are unemployed (not underemployed), with numbers not that much lower in many other sciences, where is this "real" skill gap? If anything it shows the stupidity of choosing such difficult and expensive fields where finding work is not easy and technical obsolesence, by age 50, is a very serious problem. Why should not an intelligent student simply go into nursing or pharmacy instead?

There is an easy solution to employers' problem of not finding enough technically qualified workers. Its being implemented right now.

Look up the IRS' H1B Program.

This program allows companies to hire technically qualified workers from overseas, transport them into the United States, and work them in indentured servitude for 1-2 years at wages that are supposed to be equal to the locally prevailing rate.

Abuses abound. The locally prevailing rate is set by the employer who generally underbids by 20-40% of what U.S. workers receive. H1B workers typically work extensive overtime without additional compensation. If H1B workers complain about their working conditions, they can be sent back to their country of origin.

But the pay-off for the H1B worker can be great. Employers often successfully sponsor their H1B's for U.S. citizenship, creating permanent employees with career-long depressed wages. The H1B's lower wages depress the wages of the profession as a whole - native and naturalized.

These foreign-born workers are in no way inferior to their American counterparts, and they contribute greatly to our GDP. There are advantages to scooping up the best and brightest from all over the world.

But the downside is that American workers find better paying jobs in professions that pay better. Being born here, we know the game.

If employers want qualified employees, PAY FOR THEM.

This just isn't a criticism that makes any sense. All biological parents do what they do at least in part to see their genes live on. It's a biological imperative, serving the obvious purpose of ensuring continuation of the species. It's just that for some people, propagating our genes works quickly and easily and for some people it doesn't. None of us who conceived or birthed children easily can say what we might have done if our biological motivation to see our genes live on had somehow been foiled or obstructed.

I would have some concerns in this scenario about the dangers to the grandmother's health. I can't see any real ethical contraindication; at least, not one that doesn't equally apply to all biological parents. There is no greater reason this family should have chosen to adopt than any of the rest of us.

I agree, "let all tax rates rise".

The Bush tax cuts added $2.6 trillion to public debt from 2001 - 2010.

Shared sacrifice is a desirable goal, so let ALL the Bush tax cuts expire as the original legislation required. Sacrifice for the Common Good as we are ALL in this together.
Locate where you are in the data below to determine the magnitude of your sacrifice when the Bush tax cuts expire, as they will at the end of the year.

Income Level and Average tax cut for the year.

Below $10,000. Average tax cut is $52.
$10 - $20,000. Average tax cut is $387.
$20 - $30,000. Average tax cut is $769.
$30 - $40,000. Average tax cut is $894.
$40 - $50,000. Average tax cut is $909.
$50 - $75,000. Average tax cut is $1119.

$75 - $100,000. Average tax cut is $1871.
$100 - $200,000. Average tax cut is $3690.
$200 - $500,000. Average tax cut is $7152.

$500 - $1,000,000. Average tax cut is $17,467.

$1,000,000+. Average tax cut is $103,835.

Note that the wealthy do very well in this scheme.

Data can be found here:
http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2010/09/19/weekinreview/19marsh.html?...

The median income is around $49,000. The median means half earn above $49,000 and half earn below $49,000. The average tax cut for this level is $909 or $75 per month. My tax cut is above this amount.
I am willing to give it up for the Common Good. And you?

Revenues are part of the fiscal equation. Otherwise we are locked into fiscal disaster. Do the right thing, fellow citizens.

MNW: the trouble with your theory, sadly, is that for the 30-75k brackets, that tax cut of about a grand looms HUGE.  It really will hurt those people to give it up.  I'm in the low six-figure bracket, and I'd definitely give mine up for the good of the country and to keep the greedies' mitts off my Social Security and Medicare - which I WILL need for a comfortable retirement.  I'd favor letting the tax cuts expire for $100k and above, but let the struggling lower-middle alone.

I am so tired about hearing about "job creators," as if wealthy people are, by definition creating jobs.

Here is a compromise: Create a job, here in the US at a living wage, say $20/hr. and sustain it for 2 years. Then you qualify for a a tax incentive.

Why should the American people lay sacrifices at the feet of the wealthy and pray for rain?

Some wealthy people are doing great things for the economy, support the arts and support institutions doing basic research. Thanks! And these should benefit from their largesse, through tax breaks, on philanthropy and actual investment in our economy. The "entitled class" who take the lion's share of the prosperity the stable economic environment we pay for with taxes creates, but can't bring themselves to summon any gratitude, can sulk together at the country club over martinis.

Otherwise, I'd prefer we just let all tax rates rise. The wealthy would, proportionally, pay more for this. Yes, we might stall the recovery, but business owners would also feel this pain as well as sales drop and perhaps be motivated to demand an end to the intransigence of the Tea Party ideologues in the House.

We can defeat this economic slowdown with shared sacrifice and a clear memory of what (and who) got us here in the first place.

"Even if global warming is not accepted" is close to saying "even if reality is not accepted." The cause might be debatable, whether due to natural causes or due to man made activity. The fact of increasing temperatures causing measurable changes on a planet wide basis is not open to dispute. And mankind has been very good at measuring its environment for a very long time. Probably for at least 500,000 years if tying jagged stone to sticks is one "measurable" example.
Those humans who refused to accept the reality of the "little Ice Age" when temperatures dropped probably where not among our ancestors.

Whether the attitude or values expressed are all about greed or a self-righteous attitude that believes you must suffer the consequences of any and every mistake or a conservative position that refuses to acknowledge any change these and other positions are injurious to the wellbeing of our national community. By not handling - by not admitting or recognizing - current needs we escalate future costs.

Even if global warming is not accepted, by acknowledging the positive impact green has on our world, American ingenuity could be providing new technology and jobs. Deny contraceptives and we deal with more infants who are unaffordable to the mother. We can deny health and educational resources to these "poorer" children, but someday we will pay for neglacting the child (prison or various susidies). Reduce entitlement funds and watch the curtailment of many activities (restaurant expenditures, travel, etc) which will have a negative impact on the economy.

Reduce the care, services, entitlements and the ripple effect on our lives and the economy will be huge.

Comparing Murkami to a Happy Meal because he is... popular? A more ridiculous comparison would be as hard to find as a nail in a haystack. I've read your comments about the author and his works in other articles and frankly it seems like you haven't even read his books. He writes differently than more traditionally "Japanese" authors such as Kawabata and Mishima. Yes. But does that make him a "Happy Meal" author? Are all American authors comparable to a Happy Meal, or are you saying this just because Murakami is Japanese and happens to write in a more "internationally friendly" style with a lot of pop culture references? If that is all you see in Murakami's work I recommend you to keep doing what you do instead of actually helping the world.

Murakami's fiction is popular. The McDonalds Happy Meal is too.

After the Fukushima disaster Mr. Murakami said, "We discovered hope." This kind of cheap comment meant to make people feel good really does not do any good whatsoever. Maybe the world is starved for some hope these days, but let it come from someone whose thinking is not a mass-marketed product meant to satisfy.

It is not time for Japan to fawn and indulge in another round of crocodile tears and self-flagellation over what they did in WW II. What they did in WW II is they lost the war. What China is doing now is winning the peace.

It might be time for Japan to discover some backbone before it is too late. The time has arrived for Japan to put on some muscle and act as if it has some guts. That is the lesson of Fukushima: no guts, no direct action, just people protecting their backs while others suffered and were exposed to radiation. A lesson needs to be learned here no matter how uncomfortable that lesson is. And all of this applies to China. China is going to have to be faced directly and dealt with by force eventually, and it is better to acknowledge that now than read cartoonish stories by a Japanese ex-pat who is profiting from ten million served.

That may be hard to believe for people who actually think about these things in good faith. But it is not hard to understand. Simple really. Liars lie. Republicans are liars. That's all.

the point is to provide a continuity to reality so that it is more than a series of random unrelated events. Religious historical texts focus on providing a continuity to events to emphasize the metaphysical principals that religion believes guide the world. In the west its an all perfect being with some grand plan, in daoism there isn't a plan but something more akin to a self-fulfilling methodology, in Shinto and animism it is more akin to a contest of many individual and finite wills.

Think about what justice is: it has no physical analogue, it's just a term for bringing events into concordance with our sense of right and wrong. When we apply it to history, we talk about historical injustices and justices as describing whether the continuity of events fits that sense of justice. Holy texts (or at least ones that purport to describe historical events) are the same way, they are just trying to insert and emphasize metaphysical concepts like justice or God or the Dao into the understanding of how those events transpired.

You're question posits some kind of chicken or the egg problem that doesn't apply here; people that already believe in these metaphysical principles write these texts. It is readers who feel introduced to them through the historical events: the writers that "posit" them aren't positing them in response to history, they believe history is better understood in relation to them.

Since I attended the University of Chicago, I might recall here what "Uncle Milty" (Milton Friedman) said during the Reagan deficits: "I'm not so worried about the national debt; it'll take care of itself."

We need to worry, rather, about responsibility and fairness. Responsibility means paying for the benefits (direct and indirect) we receive. Fairness means recognizing that many tax breaks let the wealthy off the hook in their responsibilty for the infrastructure that enables them to make their vast fortunes.

These two issues should concern us all. Because if the wealth of society is not distributed more widely--through wages, taxation, and benefits--eventually the entire nation will suffer. In other words, a very wealthy individual can buy only so many Rollses, private jets, and mansions. Whereas, a lot of modestly affluent people can buy a lot of Fords, airplane tickets, and single-family homes. The latter would enrich all stock holders (both figurative and literal) and the Treasury to boot.

We should all accept a national ban on saying things like "the left wants..." or "the right is trying...." Hey, the election is over. The stupidity of trying to put all issues into the left/right framework should be over for awhile, too. It just serves to harden positions and divide us more.

Second, the concluding line of this comment is made without any backing or known foundation. Thus, it is not very useful or helpful to someone who might have a different view but is open to the idea that the commenter knows or has discovered something unknown to others.

The primary "cure" for the imaginary (and real) fiscal problems of the United States is for the economy to grow robustly. When that is fully established, it will give a far better picture of what needs to be done to control spending and increase revenues. Some people were so very anxious to speed up that process because they believe the urgency will be gone once new, clear data are available and, additionally, they never wanted successful social programs, like SS and Medicare, in the first place. In other words, the idea of a crisis was being leveraged for political goals. I don't want someone suggesting ways to fix an aircraft who doesn't believe planes should fly to begin with.

http://terryreport.com

Professor Krugman has been remarkably accurate in his economic predictions over the past 7-8 years, reason enough to heed his advice.

As well, ordinary Americans have seen their assets erode and their real and nominal incomes fall over the past decade. While reported unemployment has indeed declined, keep in mind that the holders of part-time jobs paying minimum wage are not included in the unemployment statistics, nor are the many self-employed and would-be entrepreneurs who are just holding on and sometimes not even that. Americans who have been unemployed for over a year aren't counted in the jobless numbers either. Add all of these Americans to the baseline number of unemployed, and it's clear that we've still got a sick economy on our hands.

Like it or not, the federal government is the only entity that can generate sufficient demand over a short period to get America back to work. And the U.S. government can do this more cost-effectively than the private sector because it can borrow at lower interest rates.

Bottom line: we should be increasing government spending, not cutting it, until the economy revives. Once employment and output recover, federal spending cuts will be warranted. I support a +/-10-year plan to get the deficit under control, but it's a bad idea to put spending cuts into effect prematurely.

--ANetliner
